choices.B: Inspecting a sample of alerts generated from the central log repository
choices.D: Inspecting a sample of alert settings configured in the central log repository
choices.A: Comparing all servers included in the current central log repository with the listing used for the prior-year audit
choices.C: Comparing a list of all servers from the directory server against a list of all servers present in the central log repository

questions.question_text: An IS auditor concludes that logging and monitoring mechanisms within an organization are ineffective because central servers are not included within the central log repository. Which of the following audit procedures would have MOST likely identified this exception?

discussion.content: C. Comparing a list of all servers from the directory server against a list of all servers present in the central log repository

Selected Answer: C
servers to logs
C, This comparison helps ensure that all servers within the organization are included in the central log repository as intended.

choices.A: Flooding the site with an excessive number of packets
choices.D: Using a dictionary attack of encrypted passwords

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer is A. Directly related to firewall. Sniffing packets is not and more related to the protocols being used rather than the firewall itself.

Selected Answer: A
The option B describes a different type of attack known as packet sniffing or eavesdropping. While packet sniffing can pose a security risk, it typically bypasses the firewall altogether and relies on vulnerabilities in network protocols or encryption mechanisms rather than exploiting weaknesses in the firewall itself. Therefore, option A is the attack technique that will succeed because of an inherent security weakness in an Internet firewall.

Selected Answer: B
Q: attack TECHNIQUES will succeed because of an INHERENT security weakness in an Internet FIREWALL
Answer: B directly exploits weaknesses in the firewall's configuration or implementation, allowing attackers to eavesdrop on network traffic passing through the firewall.

option A DoS attack, potentially exploit weaknesses in network infrastructure, it's not directly related to inherent security weaknesses in a firewall.
option C phishing attack can bypass firewalls if conducted via email or other communication channels, they don't necessarily exploit inherent weaknesses in the firewall itself.
Cant it be Phishing???
It makes me confusing between a and b...
B. Intercepting packets and viewing passwords

questions.question_text: Which of the following attack techniques will succeed because of an inherent security weakness in an Internet firewall?
Which of the following is the BEST indication of the completeness of interface control documents used for the development of a new application?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The Option C primarily focuses on the recording of data transfers and does not necessarily guarantee the completeness of interface control documents. On the other hand, option D emphasizes the inclusion of all inputs and outputs, providing a more comprehensive indication of the completeness of interface control documents. Therefore, option D is the BEST indication in this context.

Selected Answer: D
my answer is D.

D. 
all inputs and outputs will be included.
D. All inputs and outputs for potential actions are included.
A. Failed interface data transfers prevent subsequent processes.

Selected Answer: D
Having all inputs and outputs for potential actions included in the interface control documents is considered the best indication of their completeness because it means that all necessary information required for the interfaces has been documented and accounted for. This reduces the likelihood of missing information or unexpected errors during the development and implementation of the new application. In other words, having a comprehensive and complete list of inputs and outputs helps ensure that the interface design is complete and accurately reflects the requirements and objectives of the application.
I think D

choices.B: All documents have been reviewed by end users.
choices.D: All inputs and outputs for potential actions are included.
choices.A: Failed interface data transfers prevent subsequent processes.
choices.C: Both successful and failed interface data transfers are recorded.

questions.question_text: Which of the following would BEST demonstrate that an effective disaster recovery plan (DRP) is in place?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
While frequent testing of backups (option D) is also important for verifying the integrity and recoverability of data backups, it does not provide a comprehensive assessment of the entire disaster recovery process. Full operational tests offer a more holistic approach to evaluating the effectiveness of a DRP by encompassing all aspects of disaster recovery planning and execution. Therefore, conducting a full operational test would BEST demonstrate that an effective disaster recovery plan is in place.

comments.content:
Building confidence: A successful full operational test builds confidence in the DRP and its ability to restore critical business processes in the event of a disaster. This can help to reassure stakeholders, including customers, employees, and investors, that the organization is well-prepared to handle potential disruptions.
Therefore, a full operational test is the BEST demonstration of an effective DRP. However, it should be noted that the other options, including periodic risk assessment, frequent testing of backups, and annual walk-through testing, are also important components of an effective DRP and should be performed regularly to ensure the readiness of the DRP.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A full operational test provides several benefits, including:
Identifying weaknesses in the DRP: A full operational test allows an organization to identify gaps or weaknesses in the DRP that may not have been discovered during a walk-through test or other forms of testing. This allows the organization to address these weaknesses and improve the effectiveness of the DRP.
Ensuring readiness of personnel: A full operational test provides an opportunity for personnel to practice their roles and responsibilities in a disaster scenario, which helps to ensure that they are prepared to respond effectively when a real disaster occurs.
C. Annual walk-through testing
A. Substantive testing
